I also think it sounds like a good idea.  In fact, it sounds somewhat 
similar to something I've implemented for my PhD thesis.  Great minds 
think alike!  I'd say more, but I'm about 30 days away from my defense, 
so I'm at full capacity collecting data and writing.

(There are enough differences, btw, that you should definitely keep 
going.  My stuff is intended for use on robots, I'm less interested in 
symmetry and more in repeated structure, I'm not using bilateral 
symmetry, etc.  So no worries on that front.)

I'll post my thesis to this list when it's done.

--Bryan


Kenneth Stanley wrote:
> Hi Derek, I like your choice of project.  It addresses the big 
> assumption that symmetry is beneficial to a lot of cognitive 
> processing.  By making symmetry explicity, I think it allows you to 
> get to the heart of the matter.  It also does a really good job of 
> fitting NEAT into the context of your cognitive science program.
> 
> I'm a little unsure if I'm covering all the possibilities properly 
> in my mind. I think a few activation examples might help make it 
> concrete.  For example, what if I made a network with just one 
> symmetric input and the none asymmetric output?  Is that different 
> from a network with an asymmetric input and an asymmetric output?  
> How do you read a symmetric output?  Is it interpreted as two 
> outputs?
> 
> Something that would be a great debugging tool is a visualization 
> that shows the translation from the specially-encoded network to its 
> normal graph (i.e. two side-by-side pictures).  In the second 
> picture, "symmetric" pieces would now be (I assume) pairs of 
> structures, one on each side.  Then maybe you could see the 
> contralateral crossing visually, among other things.  But it would 
> also make sure that the system means what you think it means.
> 
> I once had a different idea about symmetry in NEAT, which was to 
> take a NEAT network that is "one-sided" and reflect the entire 
> network (with the reflection having all new historical markings), 
> and then concatenate the two networks (the original and its 
> reflection) into one genome.  By "one-sided" I mean those irritating 
> bots that tend to only do thing by turning way way or another (or 
> things like that).   What I was wondering is whether once NEAT 
> discovers a one-sided strategy, it can be fairly easily duplicated 
> on the other side with little difficulty.
> 
> Of course I can see problems there.  It could create an 
> unintentional opponent process that causes the network to fight with 
> itself in some cases and end up doing nothing.  The failure cases 
> can be subtle and hard to visualize, but I think that's true in your 
> approach as well, which is why I bring this up.  What I'm wondering 
> is whether what you're doing better avoids the potentially sloppy ad-
> hocness of my idea.  I'm also wondering what you see as the pluses 
> and minuses in general, since you've been thinking about this a lot 
> recently.
> 
> Anyway, I'm sure I'll have more thoughts but hearing more about 
> activating your networks would give me a better intuitive 
> understanding.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek James" <djames@...> wrote:
>> Hi all,
>>
>>
>>
>> Just thought I'd post an update on what Philip and I have been 
> working on
>> lately, to get some feedback, but also to help me articulate the
>> implementation and some of the ideas behind it (since I'm in grad 
> school now
>> and will have to explain this to a lot of people soon anyway).
>>
>>
>>
>> I have to do a first year project as part of the PhD program I'm 
> in right
>> now, Cognitive Science at the University of Louisiana at 
> Lafayette.  I
>> decided to focus on a particular aspect of indirect encoding in 
> the context
>> of NEAT, specifically bilateral symmetry.  Most animals exhibit a 
> high
>> degree of bilateral symmetry in their overall body plan, as well 
> as their
>> neural systems.  It seemed like a logical starting point for a 
> foray into
>> indirect encoding.
>>
>>
>>
>> Anyway, I'm interested in several theoretical questions:
>>
>>
>>
>> To what extent is bilateral symmetry in an agent's neural system 
> necessary?
>> And for what kinds of cognitive tasks?
>>
>> To what extent is contralateral connectivity (connections which 
> cross the
>> midline of the neural system, i.e., are interhemispheric) 
> important, as
>> opposed to ipsilateral connectivity (connections which do not 
> cross the
>> midline, i.e., are intrahemispheric)?
>>
>>
>>
>> To try to start answering some of these questions, we extended 
> NEAT in the
>> following ways:
>>
>>
>>
>> Before, the experimenter would declare the number of input and 
> output units.
>> Now there are four parameters:
>>
>>
>>
>> inputs.asymmetrical
>>
>> outputs.asymetrical
>>
>> inputs.symmetrical
>>
>> outputs.symmetrical
>>
>>
>>
>> I'll use XOR as a running example.  To simply run XOR as before, 
> the
>> experimenter would declare 3 asymmetrical inputs (for the two data 
> inputs
>> and the bias), and one asymmetrical output.  Per the NEAT 
> paradigm, they
>> would initially be fully-connected with feedforward connections, 
> all with
>> different random initial weights.  Everything else would work as 
> before.
>>
>>
>> To run XOR under a symmetrical condition, the experimenter would 
> declare 1
>> asymmetrical input (bias), 1 symmetrical input (for the 2 data 
> inputs), and
>> 1 asymetrical output. Let's call the asymmetrical input, neuron 0, 
> the
>> symmetrical neuron 1, and the output neuron 2.
>>
>>
>>
>> When constructing the initial network, all asymmetrical neurons 
> will default
>> to the "left" of the network.  So the network now has a spatial 
> structure,
>> whereas before it was arbitrary.  So neuron 0 is on on the left, 
> along with
>> output neuron 2.  When reading the chromosome and building the 
> network,
>> neuron 1 is split into 2 copies: 1left and 1right, with identical
>> attributes.  The initial network is still fully-connected feed-
> forward, but
>> there are only 2 connection genes in the intial chromosome: 
> asymmetrical
>> connection 4 (which connects 0 and 2), and symmetrical connection 
> 5 (which
>> connects 1 and 2).  When constructed, connection 4 makes a single 
> connection
>> with a random initial weight.  Connection 5 makes 2 connections, 
> 5left and
>> 5right, connecting 1left to 2 and 1right to 2, and both 
> connections have the
>> same random initial weight.
>>
>>
>>
>> Hope that makes sense.  There are lots of ways to encode bilateral 
> symmetry.
>> We chose to make symmetry an attribute of individual genes.  It 
> may not be
>> the most biologically-inspired encoding, but we felt that it fit 
> best within
>> the context of NEAT and allowed for good control over the amount 
> and type of
>> symmetry in the evolving population.
>>
>>
>>
>> So all neuron genes now have a symmetry attribute, and all 
> connections have
>> 2 new attributes, symmetry and lateralization (indicating whether 
> they cross
>> the midline or not).
>>
>>
>>
>> Anyway, about mutations:
>>
>>
>>
>> Perturb connection weight remains unchanged, although if it 
> affects a
>> symmetrical connection, it will affect both copies created in the 
> resulting
>> network.
>>
>>
>>
>> Add neuron basically works the same as well.  If a neuron is 
> mutated on top
>> of an existing asymmetrical connection, it creates the new neuron 
> and the
>> new incoming and outgoing connections per NEAT, and all 3 new 
> features are
>> asymmetric.  If the mutation occurs on top of a symmetric 
> connection, the
>> new resulting neurons and connections will have the same symmetry 
> and
>> lateralization attributes of the connection gene they replaced.
>>
>>
>>
>> Add connection mutations are fairly complicated.  There are 2 new 
> mutation
>> rates, which control the amount of symmetry and lateralization in 
> the newly
>> mutated connections.  First, the add connection mutation rate 
> determines how
>> many new connections should be added.  Of those, the symmetry rate
>> determines the ratio that are symmetric.  Of each of those two 
> ratios, the
>> lateralization rate determines the ratio of new 
> contralateral/ipsilateral
>> connections.
>>
>>
>>
>> New connections between 2 asymmetrical neurons are asymmetrical.  
> New
>> connections between an asymmetrical neuron and a symmetrical 
> neuron can
>> either be asymmetrical or symmetrical.
>>
>>
>>
>> For a mutation between 2 symmetrical neurons, there are four 
> actual neurons
>> in the resulting network, and we allow 6 possible types of 
> connectivity to
>> mutate:
>>
>>
>>
>> symmetrical/ipsilateral    ||
>>
>> symmetric/contralateral    X
>>
>> asymmetric/ipsilateral left   |-
>>
>> asymmetric/ipsilateral right   -|
>>
>> asymmetric/contralateral left  /
>>
>> asymmetric/contralateral right  \
>>
>>
>>
>> So by adjusting the symmetry rate, we can control the amount of 
> symmetry
>> that evolves among new connections, and by adjusting the 
> lateralization
>> rate, we can control the amount of connectivity that crosses the 
> midline of
>> the network.
>>
>>
>>
>> I'm sure there are weaknesses to this encoding scheme (as I'm sure 
> some of
>> you will point out...please do).  It's now nearly completely 
> implemented in
>> ANJI (though there's still a lot of testing to be done, and we're 
> not going
>> to release it yet).
>>
>>
>>
>> I'm applying it to an active vision symmetry detection task 
> (discriminating
>> between sets of symmetrical and asymmetrical letters).  I've got 
> some
>> preliminary results, but I'm not particularly confident that 
> everything's
>> working the way it's supposed to.  This testbed is nice, since it 
> involves
>> both control aspects and pattern processing, so I'm interested to 
> see if
>> there are qualitative differences in the way symmetrically-encoded 
> and
>> asymmetrically-encoded populations solve the problem (or fail to 
> solve the
>> problem).
>>
>>
>>
>> Anyway, I hope to present this research at GECCO this summer, but 
> I thought
>> I'd expose the group to it as well and see what thoughts people 
> might have.
> 
> 
>
